articles.headline: Pete Buttigieg Fired South Bend’s Black Police Chief. It Still Stings.
articles.snippet: Mr. Buttigieg’s firing of popular black police chief Darryl Boykins unleashed a blizzard of claims, counterclaims, lawsuits and anguish in the minority community.
articles.abstract: Mr. Buttigieg’s firing of popular black police chief Darryl Boykins unleashed a blizzard of claims, counterclaims, lawsuits and anguish in the minority community.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Pete Buttigieg had been mayor just 13 weeks when he faced a leadership crisis.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Betting on the Royal Baby
articles.snippet: In Britain’s celebrity pregnancy economy, Meghan Markle’s unborn child is inspiring wagers, luxury cookie tins and diamond-encrusted jars of diaper rash cream.
articles.abstract: In Britain’s celebrity pregnancy economy, Meghan Markle’s unborn child is inspiring wagers, luxury cookie tins and diamond-encrusted jars of diaper rash cream.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Paddy Power betting website, more than $325,000 hinged on a single unborn baby.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Before Fisher-Price’s Rock ’n Play Recall, Safety Fears and Dubious Marketing
articles.snippet: The company knew for years about potential risks linked to its popular sleeper and about pediatricians’ objections to the way the product was being pitched to parents.
articles.abstract: The company knew for years about potential risks linked to its popular sleeper and about pediatricians’ objections to the way the product was being pitched to parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: The thousands of images of Fisher-Price’s Rock ’n Play sleeper posted on Instagram include many of babies snuggled serenely in the cloth-covered cradle, free of its harness and surrounded by blankets and stuffed animals.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Mueller Report Likely to Renew Scrutiny of Steele Dossier
articles.snippet: The special counsel revealed that some claims in the dossier appeared to be false while others were impossible to prove. Republicans have vowed to investigate.
articles.abstract: The special counsel revealed that some claims in the dossier appeared to be false while others were impossible to prove. Republicans have vowed to investigate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 35-page dossier, spiced up with tales of prostitutes and spies, sketched out a hair-raising story more than two years ago. Russian intelligence had used bribery and blackmail to try to turn Donald J. Trump into a source and ally, it said, and the Kremlin was running some Trump campaign aides practically as agents.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Adam Goldman and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Notre-Dame’s Safety Planners Underestimated the Risk, With Devastating Results
articles.snippet: The man who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at the cathedral said he was “stunned” at the fire’s speed. Experts said the system included delays that cost firefighters critical minutes.
articles.abstract: The man who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at the cathedral said he was “stunned” at the fire’s speed. Experts said the system included delays that cost firefighters critical minutes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The architect who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at Notre-Dame acknowledged that officials had misjudged how quickly a flame would ignite and spread through the cathedral, resulting in a much more devastating blaze than they had anticipated.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and James Glanz

articles.headline: Reaction to Mueller Report Divides Along Partisan Lines
articles.snippet: In an era of deep polarization, Mr. Mueller’s 448-page report quickly became yet another case study in the disparate realities of American politics.
articles.abstract: In an era of deep polarization, Mr. Mueller’s 448-page report quickly became yet another case study in the disparate realities of American politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats vowed on Friday to pursue the revelations in the special counsel’s report on President Trump but drew little Republican support in a nation still deeply polarized over the investigation that has dogged the White House for two years.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Should a White Man Be the Face of the Democratic Party in 2020?
articles.snippet: Interviews with several dozen Democrats show how the party, which enjoyed 2018 victories powered by female and nonwhite candidates, is grappling with questions about race and gender in the Trump era.
articles.abstract: Interviews with several dozen Democrats show how the party, which enjoyed 2018 victories powered by female and nonwhite candidates, is grappling with questions about race and gender in the Trump era.
articles.lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — As Peter Johnson and Emily Neal waited for Senator Kirsten Gillibrand to arrive at Barley’s, a brick-lined sports bar in southwestern Iowa, they gamed out possible nominees in the Democratic presidential primary.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Mozambique Cyclone Wiped Out the Nation’s Food. Now Aid Is in Short Supply.
articles.snippet: International donors gave tens of millions to help Mozambique — a far cry from the nearly one billion dollars pledged to rebuild Notre-Dame in Paris.
articles.abstract: International donors gave tens of millions to help Mozambique — a far cry from the nearly one billion dollars pledged to rebuild Notre-Dame in Paris.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASSANE, Mozambique — When the water reached their feet, the family scrambled up a mango tree. Augusto Brás, a sinewy farmer, hauled two of their children to the higher branches while his wife, Amélia Augusto, balanced on a lower bough. They clung on for three days, as the cyclone howled around them.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Claims of Shoddy Production Draw Scrutiny to a Second Boeing Jet
articles.snippet: Workers at a 787 Dreamliner plant in South Carolina have complained of defective manufacturing, debris left on planes and pressure to not report violations.
articles.abstract: Workers at a 787 Dreamliner plant in South Carolina have complained of defective manufacturing, debris left on planes and pressure to not report violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — When Boeing broke ground on its new factory near Charleston in 2009, the plant was trumpeted as a state-of-the-art manufacturing hub, building one of the most advanced aircraft in the world. But in the decade since, the factory, which makes the 787 Dreamliner, has been plagued by shoddy production and weak oversight that have threatened to compromise safety.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

articles.headline: Prodded by Putin, Russians Sought Back Channels to Trump Through the Business World
articles.snippet: The Mueller report shows how Russia’s efforts to connect with the Trump team spun into high gear after the election as the Kremlin dispatched oligarchs and bankers to find inroads.
articles.abstract: The Mueller report shows how Russia’s efforts to connect with the Trump team spun into high gear after the election as the Kremlin dispatched oligarchs and bankers to find inroads.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At 9:34 on the November morning after Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, Kirill Dmitriev, the head of Russia’s sovereign wealth fund and an informal envoy for President Vladimir V. Putin, sent a text message to a Lebanese-American friend with ties to the Trump campaign.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Blasts Targeting Christians Kill Hundreds in Sri Lanka
articles.snippet: The bombings shattered the relative calm of the once war-ravaged island nation amid a rise of religious extremism in South Asia.
articles.abstract: The bombings shattered the relative calm of the once war-ravaged island nation amid a rise of religious extremism in South Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The clock hands on the steeple of St. Anthony’s Shrine were stuck at 8:45 a.m., the exact moment when the first suicide bomber’s explosion ripped through the wooden pews as Easter Sunday worshipers were praying.
articles.byline: By Dharisha Bastians, Jeffrey Gettleman and Kai Schultz

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Came to Kansas Schools. That Started a Rebellion.
articles.snippet: Public schools in Kansas rolled out a web-based learning platform backed by Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg. Now students have staged walkouts and sit-ins. Their parents have organized.
articles.abstract: Public schools in Kansas rolled out a web-based learning platform backed by Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg. Now students have staged walkouts and sit-ins. Their parents have organized.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, Kan. — The seed of rebellion was planted in classrooms. It grew in kitchens and living rooms, in conversations between students and their parents.
articles.byline: By Nellie Bowles

articles.headline: How Michael Cohen Turned Against President Trump
articles.snippet: The president’s longtime fixer had, for months, sought “a little loving and respect.” Confidential emails and texts chronicle their momentous falling out.
articles.abstract: The president’s longtime fixer had, for months, sought “a little loving and respect.” Confidential emails and texts chronicle their momentous falling out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen was at a breaking point. He told friends he was suicidal. He insisted to lawyers he would never go to jail. Most of all, he feared that President Trump, his longtime boss, had forsaken him.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How 2020 Democrats Are Gaming Out Trump Impeachment Quandary
articles.snippet: Most candidates feel no pressure to demand President Trump’s impeachment because they do not hear a clamoring for it on the campaign trail.
articles.abstract: Most candidates feel no pressure to demand President Trump’s impeachment because they do not hear a clamoring for it on the campaign trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has worked for months to find traction in a crowded Democratic presidential primary, stepped forward on Friday with a call to arms: President Trump must be impeached.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: For Palestinian Families, ‘No Light at the End of the Tunnel’
articles.snippet: The re-election of Benjamin Netanyahu, shortly after he vowed to apply Israeli sovereignty over the West Bank, was the latest blow to Palestinian aspirations for a state.
articles.abstract: The re-election of Benjamin Netanyahu, shortly after he vowed to apply Israeli sovereignty over the West Bank, was the latest blow to Palestinian aspirations for a state.
articles.lead_paragraph: NABLUS, West Bank — Dina Teeti, 23, tries to tune out politics. But a few weeks ago, around the time Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he planned to begin annexing parts of the West Bank, she turned to her father with a heartfelt question:
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Miriam Berger

articles.headline: It’s U.S. vs. World as Big Tech Faces Specter of Limiting Speech Online
articles.snippet: Many other countries are adopting or considering stricter moderation of online speech. But they don’t have to work around the First Amendment.
articles.abstract: Many other countries are adopting or considering stricter moderation of online speech. But they don’t have to work around the First Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook called for regulating harmful internet content in an opinion column last month, Republicans in Washington expressed outrage that he was calling on the government to regulate speech.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Trump’s Washing Machine Tariffs Stung Consumers While Lifting Corporate Profits
articles.snippet: New research shows how a move meant to aid domestic manufacturers instead padded profits and raised prices on a wide variety of laundry items.
articles.abstract: New research shows how a move meant to aid domestic manufacturers instead padded profits and raised prices on a wide variety of laundry items.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s decision to impose tariffs on imported washing machines has had an odd effect: It raised prices on washing machines, as expected, but also drove up the cost of clothes dryers, which rose by $92 last year.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Decide Whether Landmark Civil Rights Law Applies to Gay and Transgender Workers
articles.snippet: The justices must decide if a law that forbids employment discrimination based on sex also bars discrimination based on sexual orientation or transgender status.
articles.abstract: The justices must decide if a law that forbids employment discrimination based on sex also bars discrimination based on sexual orientation or transgender status.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would decide whether the Civil Rights Act of 1964 guarantees protections from workplace discrimination to gay and transgender people in three cases expected to provide the first indication of how the court’s new conservative majority will approach L.G.B.T. rights.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: U.S. Moves to Stop All Nations From Buying Iranian Oil, but China Is Defiant
articles.snippet: Oil prices rose to their highest levels since October in anticipation of Monday’s announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Trump administration officials had debated the move.
articles.abstract: Oil prices rose to their highest levels since October in anticipation of Monday’s announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Trump administration officials had debated the move.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In tightening sanctions on Iran, the Trump administration moved on Monday to isolate Tehran economically and undercut its power across the Middle East. But the clampdown has complicated relations with China at a particularly sensitive moment.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Sri Lankans Mourn Victims of Easter Sunday Bombings
articles.snippet: The day after coordinated attacks on churches and hotels across Sri Lanka, one Catholic neighborhood mourned its dead.
articles.abstract: The day after coordinated attacks on churches and hotels across Sri Lanka, one Catholic neighborhood mourned its dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEGOMBO, Sri Lanka — The little room, like much of Sri Lanka, could hold no more grief.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Dharisha Bastians
